caption_original: In partnership with Nature Conservancy of Canada / Conservation de la nature Canada, the Government of Canada is investing more than $2 million through the Natural Areas Conservation Program to support the protection of an additional 47 hectares of old-growth forest lands in the heart of the Oak Ridges Moraine, the southern Ontario's most significant landforms. caption_original:
Kathy is a Senior Research Scientist at Environment and Climate Change Canada and a Professor of Wildlife Ecology at the University of B.C. Kathy studies the ecology and life history of alpine and arctic songbirds and grouse across different elevations.  Her research program has led to about 200 scientific papers, changes in forest operational practices and management recommendations for endangered species. 

Kathy received the Ian McTaggart Cowan Lifetime achievement award in 2016 which recognizes individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the understanding, conservation and/or management of wildlife in Canada over their career. #BecauseOfHer

Her research program has led to about scientific papers, changes in forest operational practices and management recommendations for endangered species. Kathy received the Ian McTaggart Cowan Lifetime achievement award in which recognizes individuals who have made outstanding contributions to the understanding, conservation and/or management of wildlife in Canada over their career.

caption_original:
The St. Lawrence River is a complex ecosystem with many different habitats that are home to many different plants, fish and animals. Wastewater and agricultural runoff release phosphorus and nitrogen into the river causing aquatic plants to thrive in what are called ‚Äúalgae blooms‚Äù. These blooms reduce oxygen available for fish and other aquatic animals. The more often phosphorus and nitrogen levels exceed guidelines, the greater the risk to the river's ecosystem health. 

Check out the current status of the St. Lawrence in our environmental indicators release! http://ow.ly/GW0D3057xxJ

These blooms reduce oxygen available for fish and other aquatic animals. The more often phosphorus and nitrogen levels exceed guidelines, the greater the risk to the river's ecosystem health. Check out the current status of the St. Lawrence in our environmental indicators release!
